facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 11, 12, 1963, of the Gujarat High Court in First Appeal No. 428 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 11, 12, 1963, of the Gujarat High Court in First Appeal No. 428 of 1962 from Original Decree.

facts.text: Election to the Assembly seat contested by three candidates: the appellant, respondent No. 1 and respondent No. 2.

anchor.surface_text: The election to the Assembly seat was contested by three candidates, the appellant, respondent No. 1 and respondent No. 2.

facts.text: Appellant secured 20,062 votes, first respondent 15,190 votes, second respondent 7,093 votes.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant having secured 20,062 votes as against 15.190 secured by the first respondent and 7,093 by the second respondent,

facts.text: Appellant declared elected on February 26, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: was declared to be elected on February 26, 1962.

facts.text: First respondent preferred an election petition challenging appellant's election on five grounds.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent thereupon preferred an election petition before the Election Commission challenging the appellants election

facts.text: Ground 1: Second respondent had not completed 25 years of age on date of scrutiny of nomination papers; acceptance improper; result materially affected.

anchor.surface_text: That the second respondent had not completed 25 years of age on the date of the scrutiny of the nomination papers, that the acceptance of his nomination paper was improper

facts.text: Ground 2: Appellant guilty of corrupt practices - bribed voters and undue influence.

anchor.surface_text: that the appellant was guilty of corrupt practices because he and his agents had bribed the voters and had also brought undue influence

facts.text: Ground 3: Appellant procured bus No. GTA 7673 for taking voters from village Sodpur to polling booths.

anchor.surface_text: that the appellant and his agents procured bus No. GTA 7673 for taking the voters from village Sodpur to and from the polling booths

facts.text: Ground 4: Appellant issued leaflets with star symbol prefixed by 'Dhruva' to appeal on religion.

anchor.surface_text: that the appellant and his agents had issued and widely distributed leaflets with star as a symbol prefixed by the word Dhruva with a view to give religious impetus

facts.text: Tribunal rejected all corrupt practice allegations against appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal rejected all the allegations relating to corrupt practices made against the appellant

facts.text: Tribunal held second respondent's nomination improperly accepted due to not attaining 25 years at scrutiny; set aside appellant's election.

anchor.surface_text: It, however, held that the second respondents nomination paper had been improperly accepted because he had not attained the age of 25 at the date of scrutiny

facts.text: High Court reversed Tribunal's finding on second respondent's age, holding he completed 25 on January 6, 1962, prior to scrutiny.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal the High Court reversed the finding of the Tribunal regarding the age of the second respondent and held that he having completed the age of 25 on January 6, 1962

facts.text: High Court held appellant guilty of corrupt practice by appealing on religion using Dhruva star; affirmed setting aside election.

anchor.surface_text: It, however, affirmed the ultimate decision of the Tribunal on the ground that the appellant and the Swatantra Party to which he belonged had been guilty of a corrupt practice

facts.text: Election Commission allotted star as symbol to Swatantra Party.

anchor.surface_text: It is not disputed that the Election Commission has allotted star as a symbol to the Swatantra Party which had put forward the appellant as its candidate.

facts.text: Leaflets described election symbol as Dhruva star or Pole Star, listing qualities: eternal, firm, guide, determined, devoted to religion.

anchor.surface_text: Nor is it disputed that in some of the leaflets and pamphlets distributed by or on behalf of the appellant the election symbol of the Swatantra Party is described as the star Dhruva

facts.text: Supreme Court held Dhruva star not a religious symbol; no corrupt practice under S.123(3).

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the opinion that the High Court was in error in reversing the judgment of the Tribunal on this point.

facts.text: Supreme Court accepted High Court's finding on second respondent's age based on school certificates.

anchor.surface_text: In so far as the age of the second respondent is concerned the High Court has fully considered the evidence and has rightly rejected the entries

facts.text: First respondent did not press other points before High Court, focused on corrupt practice.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Daru, the learned advocate for the first respondent before us, has been content with arguing the case of the first respondent before us on the basis of a corrupt practice

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 506 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 506 of 1964.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Mudholkar J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Mudholkar J.

facts.text: Appellant belongs to Swatantra Party.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant and the Swatantra Party to which he belonged had been guilty of a corrupt practice

facts.text: High Court judgment delivered by K. T. Desai C.J.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of the Court was delivered by K. T. Desai C.J.

facts.text: No direct appeal to religious sentiments in any pamphlet.

anchor.surface_text: Not a single pamphlet or leaflet is alleged to have been distributed by or at the instance of the appellant in which a direct appeal

sub-s.  3  of S. 123 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951  hereinafter referred to as the Act  by reason of the fact that his election symbol, a star, was described as Dhruva star in the pamphlets published and distributed by him or by his agents and in which the qualities of Dhruva star were also set out.

concepts.interpretation: Prohibits appeal to vote on grounds of religion etc. or use of/appeal to religious symbols for furthering election prospects. Court holds describing party symbol 'star' as 'Dhruva star' with its qualities does not violate as Dhruva star lacks special religious significance and is not a deity; no direct appeal to religious sentiment made.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: to be declared void by reason of the companyrupt practice that has been companymitted at the elec- tion with the companysent of the appellant before u

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 123(3) Representation of the People Act, 1951
concepts.unlisted_description: Defines corrupt practice of appealing on religion or using religious symbols in elections

anchor.surface_text: Section 123 of the Act sets out what shall be deemed to be companyrupt practices for the purposes of the Act. Sub-section  3  thereof provides as follows The following shall be deemed to be companyrupt practices for the purposes of this Act The appeal by a candidate or his agent or by any other person with the companysent of a candidate or his election agent to vote or refrain from voting for any person on the ground of his religion, race, caste, companymunity or language or the use of, or appeal to, religious symbols or the use of, or appeal to, national symbols, such as the national flag or the national emblem, for the furtherance of the prospects of the election of that can-

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 123(3) Representation of the People Act, 1951

anchor.surface_text: the provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure have numberapplication to appeals brought by special leave under Art. 136 of the Constitution and observed We have numberappeal before us on behalf of the respondents and we are unable to allow that question to be re-agitated.

concepts.interpretation: Court holds it has jurisdiction in SLP appeals to decide all points arising from impugned judgment, including allowing respondent to support decree on grounds rejected below, overruling narrow view in Vashist Narain Sharma; can adopt CPC provisions analogously.

anchor.surface_text: any provision analogous to XLI, r. 22 of the Code of Civil Procedure which permits a party to support the judgment appealed against upon a ground which has been found against him in that judgment.

concepts.interpretation: Supreme Court can draw upon this CPC provision analogously in SLP appeals despite no direct application, to permit respondent to support judgment on rejected grounds.
concepts.unlisted_description: Permits respondent to support decree on grounds decided against it below

anchor.surface_text: The provision nearest to it is the one companytained in 0. XVIII, r. 3 of the Rules of this Court which requires parties to file statement of cases. Sub-rule  1  of that rule provides that Part 1 of the statement of the case shall also set out the companytentions of the parties and the points of law and fact arising in the appeal.

concepts.interpretation: Requires parties to set out contentions and points of law/fact in statement of case; not limited to favorable findings.
concepts.unlisted_label: Order XVIII Rule 3 Supreme Court Rules

concepts.interpretation: Election pamphlets/posters to be construed fairly, objectively, reasonably, allowing for hyperbole and partisan atmosphere; courts should not read more than apparent on face or be astute to infer mischief under S.123(3).
concepts.unlisted_label: Fair and Reasonable Construction of Election Literature
concepts.unlisted_description: Doctrine for interpreting election propaganda to determine corrupt practice

anchor.surface_text: As pointed out by this Court in Jagdev Singh Sidhanti v. Pratap Singh Daulta Ors.  1  the question has to be examined in two branches whether the symbol used has any special religious significance and whether its inscription on leaflets and pamphlets which were distributed amounts to the use of a religious symbol.

concepts.interpretation: Two-branch test: (1) does symbol have special religious significance? (2) does its use in materials amount to use/appeal to religious symbol? Dhruva star fails both.

anchor.surface_text: It is impossible to say that any particular object, bird, or animal could be regarded as a symbol of the Hindu religion. The basic concept of Hindu religion is that the supreme being

arguments.claim: Cock symbol case distinguishable; corrupt practice there due to nature of appeal threatening miseries, not mere symbol

anchor.surface_text: The conclusion of this Court was based not upon the mere fact of the use of the symbol of cock but it was based upon the nature of the appeal for votes made by the cock.

arguments.claim: Election literature requires fair, reasonable, objective construction allowing for hyperbole; not to infer more than face value
SC has jurisdiction in Art.136 SLP appeals to permit respondent to support judgment on grounds rejected below, analogous to CPC O.41 r.22

holdings.text: The appellant is not guilty of the corrupt practice under Section 123(3) of the Representation of the People Act, 1951, by describing the election symbol 'star' as 'Dhruva star' and setting out its qualities in pamphlets.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the opinion that the High Court was in error in reversing the judgment of the Tribunal on this point.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dhruva star lacks special religious significance as Dhruva is not a deity but a devotee; qualities are universal, not religiously peculiar; no direct appeal to religious sentiment; fair and reasonable construction of election literature required per Kultar Singh; applies two-branch test from Jagdev Singh Sidhanti.

holdings.text: The use of 'Dhruva star' does not amount to use of or appeal to a religious symbol under Section 123(3).

anchor.surface_text: As pointed out by this Court in Jagdev Singh Sidhanti v. Pratap Singh Daulta Ors.  1  the question has to be examined in two branches whether the symbol used has any special religious significance and whether its inscription on leaflets and pamphlets which were distributed amounts to the use of a religious symbol.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fails two-branch test: no special religious significance (Dhruva not divine, qualities not peculiar to Hinduism); no arousal of religious sentiment; distinguishable from cock symbol case; no particular symbol represents Hinduism.

holdings.text: The second respondent's nomination was properly accepted as he had completed 25 years of age prior to scrutiny.

anchor.surface_text: In so far as the age of the second respondent is concerned the High Court has fully considered the evidence and has rightly rejected the entries

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court correctly reversed Tribunal after full evidence consideration, accepting school certificates over police register entries.

holdings.text: In appeals by special leave under Article 136, the respondent may support the impugned judgment on grounds rejected below, analogous to Order XLI Rule 22 CPC; disapproves narrow view in Vashist Narain Sharma.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the opinion that in Vasisht Narain Sharmas case 1 too narrow a view was taken regarding the powers of this Court and we over-rule the preliminary objection of Mr. S. T. Desai.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Upon grant of special leave, full appeal arises; Court exercises civil jurisdiction, can adopt CPC provisions analogously for justice; Order XVIII R3 SC Rules not limiting; policy requires permitting support on rejected grounds.

holdings.text: Election literature must be construed fairly, reasonably, objectively, allowing for hyperbole in partisan atmosphere; courts should not infer more than apparent or be astute to find mischief under S.123(3).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies doctrine from Kultar Singh: realistic view of election propaganda; not strict/literal; High Court erred by reading more into pamphlets.
